commit_message:
Adds service_types to client_plugins

service_types is added to client_plugins to support the
conditional resource plugin availability.

implements blueprint: keystone-based-resource-availability

Change-Id: I28d606416acd1d47a09f3c62b5236b5f53583f60
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/29/192529/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: service_types = ['database']

subject: Remove hardcoded http in URL in sahara exercise script
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-08 21:30:28.000000000', 'files': ['exercises/sahara.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/ce2d75df01071a06ac08c8f5ba73a8fd78002da4', 'message': 'Remove hardcoded http in URL in sahara exercise script

The script hardcoded http://$SERVICE_HOST/... which failed
when SSL or tls-proxy was enabled. Calculate the protocol
based on enabled services instead.

Change-Id: I192eeeafe7bf4dc5cbd382c505ffb9307651d78a
'}]
commit_message:
Remove hardcoded http in URL in sahara exercise script

The script hardcoded http://$SERVICE_HOST/... which failed
when SSL or tls-proxy was enabled. Calculate the protocol
based on enabled services instead.

Change-Id: I192eeeafe7bf4dc5cbd382c505ffb9307651d78a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/75/189475/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if is_ssl_enabled_service "sahara" || is_service_enabled tls-proxy; then SAHARA_SERVICE_PROTOCOL="https" fi SAHARA_SERVICE_PROTOCOL=${SAHARA_SERVICE_PROTOCOL:-$SERVICE_PROTOCOL} $CURL_GET $SAHARA_SERVICE_PROTOCOL://$SERVICE_HOST:8386/ 2>/dev/null | grep -q 'Auth' || die $LINENO "Sahara API isn't functioning!"
deleted_lines: $CURL_GET http://$SERVICE_HOST:8386/ 2>/dev/null | grep -q 'Auth' || die $LINENO "Sahara API isn't functioning!"

commit_message:
Make sure iptables-services is installed

The iptables service files are no longer included by default on
Fedora.  This causes the systemctl calls in fixup_stuff.sh to fail
when disabling firewalld in favor of iptables.

Change-Id: If37691d03e3d07ca8b53c541717081beeb184c16
Closes-Bug: #1462347
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/70/188870/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The iptables service files are no longer included by default install_package iptables-services

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-17 16:21:18.000000000', 'files': ['tooz/drivers/file.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tooz/commit/c43590a44f9eae0b9333d665de599008f9e65275', 'message': 'Remove file-driver special no-async abilities

To enable a following commit to unify the `run_watchers` of
the various drivers we need to make the file driver method
look more like the other drivers, which means removing the
special no-async ability and having it use the standard get
a future and wait on it to return (and repeat).

Change-Id: I14d227a0e6a80da80eb2580b1780ae1dba128b21
'}]
commit_message:
Remove file-driver special no-async abilities

To enable a following commit to unify the `run_watchers` of
the various drivers we need to make the file driver method
look more like the other drivers, which means removing the
special no-async ability and having it use the standard get
a future and wait on it to return (and repeat).

Change-Id: I14d227a0e6a80da80eb2580b1780ae1dba128b21
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/58/192758/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fut = self._submit(_do_get_members) return FileFutureResult(fut) def get_groups(self): fut = self._submit(_do_get_groups) group_members_fut = self.get_members(group_id) group_members = group_members_fut.get(timeout=None) self._group_members[group_id].update(group_members) w = timeutils.StopWatch(duration=timeout) w.start() leftover_timeout = w.leftover(return_none=True) known_groups = self.get_groups().get(timeout=leftover_timeout) leftover_timeout = w.leftover(return_none=True) try: group_members_fut = self.get_members(group_id) group_members = group_members_fut.get(timeout=leftover_timeout)
deleted_lines: fut = self._get_members(group_id) return FileFutureResult(fut) def _get_members(self, group_id, async=True): if async: return self._submit(_do_get_members) else: return _do_get_members() def _get_groups(self, async=True): if async: return self._submit(_do_get_groups) else: return _do_get_groups() def get_groups(self): fut = self._get_groups() members = self._get_members(group_id, async=False) self._group_members[group_id].update(members) known_groups = self._get_groups(async=False) try: group_members = self._get_members(group_id, async=False)

commit_message:
Add side-by-side comparison of v2 and v3 APIs

There was no document for the differences between the
v2.0 and v3 APIs.

Change-Id: Ib17ecb78d09822b5288ef82f71b433110e9a9f84
Closes-Bug: #1194885

commit_message:
neutron: remove deprecated allow_duplicate_networks config option

Commit 4306d9190f49e7fadf88669d18effedabc880d3b deprecated the
allow_duplicate_networks config option in Kilo and marked it for removal
in Liberty where the default behavior is to just allow duplicate
networks.

This simply removes the option and checks/tests around it being False.

DocImpact: Removed neutron.allow_duplicate_networks config option. The
           behavior in Liberty is now to simply allow duplicate
           networks.

Change-Id: Icb3510bcf0c30e11d0304a86ead91a43f37602ec

commit_message:
logging failed exception info for add image operation

Add image operation failed will lead to rollback operation,
delete this image if it was created.
If this operation throws some exception, previous one will be
overwritten so that we cannot elegantly trace the problem occurs.
We could log failed exception info before rollback operation.

Change-Id: Ie2efcedbd647adb827f40c2ef6673c615046c6a4
modified:   glance_store/_drivers/rbd.py
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/66/193066/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make the 3PAR drivers honor the pool in create

Updated 3PAR's usage of the extra spec setting hp3par:cpg. This
setting is ignored in Kilo; the hp3par_cpg setting in cinder.conf
should be used instead.
Closes-Bug: 1434292

Change-Id: Idac6b7b2aaa04e06bc9066a38d52683da70395ee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/43/192943/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <warning><para>This setting is ignored as of Kilo. Instead, use the <literal>hp3par_cpg</literal> setting in <filename> cinder.conf</filename> to list the valid CPGs for a backend. CPGs should now be controlled by configuring separate backends with pools.</para></warning>

commit_message:
Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new
versions of the libraries without namespace packages will be released as
a major version update.

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

Blueprint: remove-namespace-packages
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/remove-namespace-packages

Change-Id: I7344c794b73aca1e0dcad681a4c43e3a66dd2eb3

Drop use of 'oslo' namespace package

The Oslo libraries have moved all of their code out of the 'oslo'
namespace package into per-library packages. The namespace package was
retained during kilo for backwards compatibility, but will be removed by
the liberty-2 milestone. This change removes the use of the namespace
package, replacing it with the new package names.

The patches in the libraries will be put on hold until application
patches have landed, or L2, whichever comes first. At that point, new

Please merge this patch, or an equivalent, before L2 to avoid problems
with those library releases.

commit_message:
Allow ``OS_DEBUG`` environment variable to specify log level.

Preserve original behavior when ``OS_DEBUG`` is ``True``, but if variable
is set to a valid log level, such as 'WARNING' use that level instead to
allow finer grained control over verbosity of log messages with the
FakeLogger.

Change-Id: I6594cec8de6fa221fe81f663a9126b2df8762ef3
Closes-Bug: 1280454

commit_message:
Get rid of oslo-incubator copy of middleware

We have already moved all projects away from openstack/common/middleware
modules to the oslo_middlware library. We don't need these files here
anymore.

Change-Id: I1b4cfa4a8a318d83ac107f3f631c9f1fd24178f9

commit_message:
Revert "timeutils: deprecate isotime()"

This reverts commit 5cad113739fa906c3901e530fcbfdee3b48961c1.

The deprecation message says to use datetime.datetime.isoformat()
instead, but the format of the string generated by isoformat isn't
the same as the format of the string generated by isotime. The string
is used in tokens generated by keystone and other public APIs so the
format generated by isotime must continue to be used otherwise we'd
be violating the OpenStack API stability guideline. The function is
used in both keystone and keystoneclient, so if this isn't in a
common place like oslo.utils then we need to copy-paste the code
into multiple projects.

Change-Id: Iaa732bdf8597835f2422b3e984c35397e3637e01
Closes-Bug: 1461251
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/23/189523/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def isotime(at=None, subsecond=False): """Stringify time in ISO 8601 format."""def iso8601_from_timestamp(timestamp, microsecond=False): """Returns an iso8601 formatted date from timestamp."""
deleted_lines: @removals.remove( message="use datetime.datetime.isoformat()", version="1.6", removal_version="?", ) def isotime(at=None, subsecond=False): """Stringify time in ISO 8601 format. .. deprecated:: > 1.5.0 Use :func:`utcnow` and :func:`datetime.datetime.isoformat` instead. """@removals.remove( message="use datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp().isoformat()", version="1.6", removal_version="?", ) def iso8601_from_timestamp(timestamp, microsecond=False): """Returns an iso8601 formatted date from timestamp. .. deprecated:: > 1.5.0 Use :func:`datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp` and :func:`datetime.datetime.isoformat` instead. """

commit_message:
Move files into the right spot and get tests working

* Move files from keystone folder into appropriate folders
* Move tests from keystone into appropriate folders
* Fix imports to use the new module locations
* Add a _i18n.py to help with localication
* Add a BaseTestcase class
* Add a exceptions module

All just enough to run the tests. Though some tests were commented
with a FIXME to be fixed in later commits.

A few additional tests were not working with py34 and they are
skipped using testtools.skipIf statements.

Change-Id: Ib494d2a960cab5959c2adaca1eb0739fe65d14f1

commit_message:
Don't sanitize node names for log directories

The naming of nodes has recently changed so this is no longer needed. We
used to do it to strip out the random part of node names in order to
assist searching.

Change-Id: If9bdeb898016e67e873566c8bde12c8bf2d08b70

commit_message:
Python 3: do not use cmp(), nor sorted(..., cmp=...)

* The "cmp" function has been removed, so we must not use it any more;
* The "cmp" keyword argument of the "sorted" function has been removed, so
  replace it with "key=functool.cmp_to_key".

Change-Id: Ic39d29dc1002a68f36f04c32e53a36bc826dce78
Blueprint: neutron-python3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/18/192718/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import functools ret = (obj1[key] > obj2[key]) - (obj1[key] < obj2[key]) return sorted(items, key=functools.cmp_to_key(cmp_func))
deleted_lines: ret = cmp(obj1[key], obj2[key]) return sorted(items, cmp=cmp_func)

commit_message:
Remove usage of WritableLogger from oslo_log

With Eventlet 0.17.2, we can directly pass the logger
instance. This allows us to deprecate/remove the WritableLogger
class from oslo.log.

Closes-Bug: #1440773
Change-Id: I3985b30b499a1e676d39c2a6cd3a31ac13c0ab47

added_lines: 'log': self._logger,

commit_message:
Adopt oslo guru meditation report to Keystone

This spec proposes adoption for Oslo Guru Meditation reports in Keystone.
The new feature will enhance debugging capabilities of all official
Keystone services, by providing an easy way to gather runtime data about
current threads and configuration, among other things, to developers,
operators, and tech support.

blueprint guru-meditation-report

Change-Id: I40461f01039c2a1fa8e7f61f531f07bd23769d03
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/72/184172/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== Adopt Oslo Guru Meditation Reports =================================== `bp guru-meditation-report <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/guru-meditation-report>`_ This spec adopts Oslo Guru Meditation Reports in Keystone. The feature will enhance debugging capabilities of all Keystone services, by providing an easy and convenient way to collect debug data about current threads and configuration, among other things, to developers, operators, and tech support in production deployments. Problem Description =================== Currently,Keystone doesn't provide a way to collect state data from active service processes. The only information that is available to deployers, developers, and tech support is what was actually logged by the service. Additional data could be usefully used to debug and solve problems that occur during Keystone operation. We could be interested in stack traces of green and real threads, pid/ppid info, package version, configuration as seen by the service, etc. Oslo Guru Meditation Reports provide an easy way to add support for collecting the live state info from any service. Report generation is triggered by sending a special(USR1) signal to a service. Reports are generated on stderr, and can be piped into system log based on need. Nova has supported Oslo Guru Meditation Reports. Proposed Change =============== First, the oslo-incubator module (reports.*) should be synchronized into keystone tree. Then, each service process needs to initialize the error report system prior to the service start(). Alternatives ------------ None Security Impact --------------- In theory, the change could expose service internals to someone who is able to send the needed signal to a service. That said, we can probably assume that the user is already authorized to achieve a lot more than just having an access to stack traces and configuration used. Also, if deployers are afraid of the information leak for some reason, they could also make sure their stderr output is channeled into safe place. Because this report is triggered by user, there is no need to add config option to turn on/off this feature. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ The feature does not require any additional resources until it's triggered by the user. Default report generation is not expected to take too long. Report extensions will need to be assessed on case by case basis. In any case, reports are not expected to be generated too often and are assumed to be debugging capability, not something to trigger once per minute just in case. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers may be interested in making sure those reports are collected 98 somewhere (e.g. stderr should be captured by syslog). Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: liusheng<liusheng@huawei.com> Work Items ---------- * sync reports.* module from oslo-incubator * adopt it in all keystone services under keystone/cmd/ * add some developer docs on how to use this feature Dependencies ============ reports.* module is currently going thru graduation consideration. In case it's graduated into oslo.reports library before Keystone switches to it, we won't actually need to sync any code from oslo-incubator but instead add a new external oslo dependency. If Keystone switches to the module before graduation is complete, then we'll need to adopt oslo.reports later as part of usual oslo liaison effort. Documentation Impact ==================== description about this feature should be added to user documentation and developer documentation. References ========== * `oslo-incubator <http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/oslo-incubator/tree/openstack/common/report>`_ * `Nova guru meditation reports <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/guru-meditation-report>`_ * `blog about nova guru reports <https://www.berrange.com/posts/2015/02/19/nova-and-its-use-of-olso-incubator-guru-meditation-reports/>`_ * `oslo.reports repo <https://github.com/directxman12/oslo.reports>`_

commit_message:
Enable Orchestration in DevStack

Heat is configured by default on DevStack for
Icehouse and Juno releases. Newer versions of
OpenStack require enabling Heat services in
DevStack local.conf.

Change-Id: I236178edab04999852d41590aeb2210a23c1a66f

commit_message:
Wrong config file is used for the M2 plug-in

The install-guide advises to edit the [ovs] section inside the
 /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini file. However, this file
 doesn't contain any [ovs] section. Instead, the install-guide
 should advise to use
 /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini,
 which contains the section, and which should be used for
 editing the [ovs] section.

Change-Id: I7c410752b41e3f5e423bdde1f0546309f34e84a8
Closes-Bug: #1422038
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/93/171093/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <filename>/etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini</filename> <note os="debian"> <para>Note that, in Debian both <filename>/etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini</filename> and <filename>/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini</filename> files are in use for the ML2 plugin agent.</para> </note> <note os="ubuntu"> <para>Note that, in Ubuntu <filename>/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini</filename> file is used for the ML2 plugin agent.</para> </note>

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-07 09:08:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/b4bda3ffb62fa2e9be2efd3b69996bc8058b10cc', 'message': "Add dnsmasq_dns_servers = <some-dns-server> as a parameter in dhcp_agent.ini

Current /etc/neutron/dhcp_agent.ini in the installation guide doesn't
specify the dns-servers to be included in its configuration.

Due to this, DNS will not work in the demo-instance created in Chapter 14
because dnsmasq will not know how to handle the request in the demo-net.
ping -c openstack.org will fail without the proper forwader.

Correcting this by adding comma-separated list of DNS servers which will
be used by dnsmasq as forwarders.

Closes-Bug : #1439369

Change-Id: I9932f1c7e731a142bd097e3f35293777a397b9b3
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-04-08 10:42:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/86f5f156b934ef7f39dee1dc8cb0016b98294619', 'message': "Missing DNS forwarder config in subnet creation

dnsmasq will not know how to handle the request in the demo-net.
ping -c openstack.org will fail without the proper forwader.

Correcting this by adding '--dns-nameservers list=true 8.8.8.8 8.8.4.4'
to the demo subnet creation.

commit_message:
Missing DNS forwarder config in subnet creation

DNS will not work in the demo-instance created in Chapter 14 because
dnsmasq will not know how to handle the request in the demo-net.
ping -c openstack.org will fail without the proper forwader.

Correcting this by adding '--dns-nameservers list=true 8.8.8.8 8.8.4.4'
to the demo subnet creation.

backport: juno icehouse
Closes-Bug: #1439369

Change-Id: I9932f1c7e731a142bd097e3f35293777a397b9b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/88/171088/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: dnsmasq_dns_servers = <replaceable>DNS_SERVERS</replaceable> <para>Replace <replaceable>DNS_SERVERS</replaceable> with a comma-separated list of DNS servers which will be used by dnsmasq as forwarders.</para>

commit_message:
Fixes parameter order for neutron subnet-create

The order for the parameters of neturon subnet-create
is incorrect. The name of the network to which this
subnet belongs to must be placed before the CIDR.
This change fixes the placement.

Change-Id: I381e5bf66e11a6fea400737d351798033d946ae9
Closes-Bug: #1460029
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/25/186725/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $ neutron subnet-create --name ext-subnet --allocation-pool \ --gateway 203.0.113.1 ext-net 203.0.113.0/24

commit_message:
Add step to restart rabbitmq service

Add a step to restart the rabbitmq service
to avoid problems, e.g. swift authentification with keystone.

Change-Id: Iedd915d4ab309b3b0f0267d5d38ffa1e837a8521
Closes-Bug: #1458988

commit_message:
Uncap pytz

pytz is a pretty small project without any dependencies of it's own so
it's not a transitive dependency creep risk, and Babel requires it
uncapped, so capping it in g-r is probably not a safe idea given pycadf
is using it and now has a stable/icehouse branch.

So let's uncap pytz and avoid a future gate wedge in stable/icehouse.

Change-Id: I3ca651a4377d61be3fed572355326bc180ad7eec

Setting the content-length header to string

- Something changed in wsgi that does not like header values as int

Change-Id: I1ad40e68038df0366c98a8927dfa5f21595e68a7

commit_message:
Allow default reseller prefix in domain_remap middleware

Previously, the reseller prefix needed to be provided in the host name
even when the domain was unique to that reseller. With the
default_reseller_prefix, any domain which matches in this middleware,
will will be passed on with a reseller prefix, whether or not it was
provided.

Change-Id: I5aa5ce78ad1ee2e3660cce4c3e07306f8999f02a
Implements: blueprint domainremap-reseller-domains

commit_message:
Move get_inteface_by_ip from LinuxBridge class to ip_lib

get_interface_by_ip is moved fro LinuxBridgeManager to ip_lib
as a more generic get_device_by_ip.

System-faking unit tests have been switched for functional
testing that also performs a negative test.

This can be reused in the openvswitch-agent code to validate
local_ip reusing the LinuxBridge logic.

Change-Id: I9237871a6e24dd99556c71844624be510e20d289
Related-Bug: #1464178
Related-Bug: #1408603

commit_message:
Put requirements repo in a venv.

This is to prevent any possible contamination of test results from its
presence.

Change-Id: I5a929854745650cc6a182ffc4d15c50caabdd727

In order to migrate to Zanata for translations, we need to modify
the proposal scripts to also upload translations to the Zanata
server. This commit supports most projects (those that make use of
upstream_translation_update.sh), as well as django_openstack_auth.

This does not impact the existing push and pull of
translations to Transifex, and also untouched are the translations
for Horizon or the manuals, which are all handled in separate scripts.

Co-Authored-By: stephane <stephane@alum.mit.edu>
Change-Id: I3bfb188c8b0c0e65f22d7edc30721b163f084fff

commit_message:
Support pushing translations to Zanata

In order to migrate to Zanata for translations, we need to modify
the proposal scripts to also upload translations to the Zanata
server. This commit supports most projects (those that make use of
upstream_translation_update.sh), as well as django_openstack_auth.

This does not impact the existing push and pull of
translations to Transifex, and also untouched are the translations
for Horizon or the manuals, which are all handled in separate scripts.

Co-Authored-By: stephane <stephane@alum.mit.edu>
Change-Id: I3bfb188c8b0c0e65f22d7edc30721b163f084fff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/13/181113/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function setup_translation_zanata { local project=$1 local version=$2 HAS_CONFIG=1 if [ ! -f zanata.xml ]; then /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/create-xml.py -p $project -v $version --srcdir ${project}/locale --txdir ${project}/locale -f zanata.xml HAS_CONFIG=0 fi } # Setup project so that git review works, sets global variable # COMMIT_MSG. Now with zanata-themed strings! function setup_review_zanata { FULL_PROJECT=$(grep project .gitreview | cut -f2 -d= |sed -e 's/\.git$//') set +e read -d '' COMMIT_MSG <<EOF Imported Translations from Zanata For more information about this automatic import see: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Translations/Infrastructure EOF set -e git review -s # See if there is an open change in the zanata/translations # topic. If so, get the change id for the existing change for use # in the commit msg. change_info=`ssh -p 29418 proposal-bot@review.openstack.org gerrit query --current-patch-set status:open project:$FULL_PROJECT topic:zanata/translations owner:proposal-bot` previous=`echo "$change_info" | grep "^ number:" | awk '{print $2}'` if [ "x${previous}" != "x" ] ; then change_id=`echo "$change_info" | grep "^change" | awk '{print $2}'` # Read returns a non zero value when it reaches EOF. Because we use a # heredoc here it will always reach EOF and return a nonzero value. # Disable -e temporarily to get around the read. set +e read -d '' COMMIT_MSG <<EOF Imported Translations from Zanata For more information about this automatic import see: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Translations/Infrastructure Change-Id: $change_id EOF set -e fi # If the open change an already approved, let's not queue a new # patch but let's merge the other patch first. # This solves the problem that when the gate pipeline backup # reaches roughly a day, no matter how quickly you approve the new # update it will always get sniped out of the gate by another. # It also helps, when you approve close to the time this job is # run. if [ "x${previous}" != "x" ] ; then # Use the JSON format since it is very compact and easy to grep change_info=`ssh -p 29418 proposal-bot@review.openstack.org gerrit query --current-patch-set --format=JSON $change_id` # Check for: # 1) Workflow approval (+1) # 2) no -1/-2 by Jenkins # 3) no -2 by reviewers # 4) no Workflow -1 (WIP) # if `echo $change_info|grep -q '{"type":"Workflow","description":"Workflow","value":"1"'` \ && ! `echo $change_info|grep -q '{"type":"Verified","description":"Verified","value":"-[12]","grantedOn":[0-9]*,"by":{"name":"Jenkins","username":"jenkins"}}'` \ && ! `echo $change_info|grep -q '{"type":"Code-Review","description":"Code-Review","value":"-2"'` \ && ! `echo $change_info|grep -q '{"type":"Workflow","description":"Workflow","value":"-1"'` ; then echo "Job already approved, exiting" exit 0 fi fi } # Propose patch using COMMIT_MSG; use zanata/translations topic function send_patch_zanata { # Revert any changes done to .tx/config if [ $HAS_CONFIG -eq 1 ]; then git reset -q zanata.xml git checkout -- zanata.xml else rm -rf zanata.xml fi # Don't send a review if nothing has changed. if [ `git diff --cached |wc -l` -gt 0 ]; then # Commit and review git commit -F- <<EOF $COMMIT_MSG EOF git review -t zanata/translations fi } # Setup transifex configuration for log level message translation. # Needs variables setup via setup_loglevel_vars. function setup_loglevel_project_zanata { project=$1 for level in $LEVELS ; do # Bootstrapping: Create file if it does not exist yet, # otherwise "tx set" will fail. if [ ! -e ${project}/locale/${project}-log-${level}.pot ]; then touch ${project}/locale/${project}-log-${level}.pot fi done }

commit_message:
Added documentation around database upgrades

Listed the current process for upgrading the Nova database to allow for
better understanding of what will be changing.

Change-Id: Ib1c6abd8b08fe0987e2535d0ed6729f5384cebf3
Signed-off-by: Philip Schwartz <philip.schwartz@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/32/191932/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Current Database Upgrade Process -------------------------------- Currently Nova has 3 steps for upgrading its database. 1. Offline database schema migrations from pre-defined migrations in nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions. 2. Offline data migrations also from pre-defined migrations in nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_\repo/versions. 3. Online data migrations from inside Nova object source code. The first of these online data migrations were added with the flavor migration and are located in nova/objects/instance.py and is a special case as there was no required schema reductions for this to work.

subject: support for keystone v3 api - add domains to service_identity
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-06 15:41:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/6ab45c2ce2dfb06e25302bfbea1c555e56d91921', 'message': 'support for keystone v3 api - add domains to service_identity

This patch implements these parts of the blueprint:

1) Adds support for domains to service_identity.
Users of this resource may specify a different domain for both the user
and the tenant/project, or may specify the default domain which will apply
to both user and tenant.  This also adds the same domain support to
keystone::endpoint since that class uses service_identity.

2) Adds a make_keystone_role_name helper method which will construct a
valid domain aware role name.  This is intended to be used in the other
puppet modules (puppet-glance) that set notifications based on
keystone_user_role resources, in order to construct valid domain aware
names for these resources.

3) Adds a new resource keystone::resource::authconfig - this manages
keystone authentication for other puppet modules by managing the
[keystone_authtoken] section in the config.  Encapsulating the
authentication configuration in this resource will ensure that we
will be able to support the several new types of authentication coming
in current and future Keystone releases.  This supports all of the
authentication options specified at:
http://www.jamielennox.net/blog/2015/02/17/loading-authentication-plugins/

3) Cleans up domain support in admin.pp and uses the new helper method

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support

Change-Id: I3d420e08c74e8a43f2431be7fd46198281438f13
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-05-06 15:48:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/26a6e022d9a3acd24e10de7c2138943a41c75eaf', 'message': 'support for keystone v3 api - add domains to service_identity

[keystone_authtoken] section in the config.  Encapsulating the
authentication configuration in this resource will ensure that we
will be able to support the several new types of authentication coming
in current and future Keystone releases.  This supports all of the
authentication options specified at:
http://www.jamielennox.net/blog/2015/02/17/loading-authentication-plugins/

4) Cleans up domain support in admin.pp and uses the new helper method

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support

Change-Id: I3d420e08c74e8a43f2431be7fd46198281438f13

commit_message:
support for keystone v3 api - add domains to service_identity

This patch implements these parts of the blueprint:

1) Adds support for domains to service_identity.
Users of this resource may specify a different domain for both the user
and the tenant/project, or may specify the default domain which will apply
to both user and tenant.  This also adds the same domain support to
keystone::endpoint since that class uses service_identity.

2) Adds a make_keystone_role_name helper method which will construct a
valid domain aware role name.  This is intended to be used in the other
puppet modules (puppet-glance) that set notifications based on
keystone_user_role resources, in order to construct valid domain aware
names for these resources.

3) Adds a new resource keystone::resource::authconfig - this manages
keystone authentication for other puppet modules by managing the
[keystone_authtoken] section in the config.  Encapsulating the
authentication configuration in this resource will ensure that we
will be able to support the several new types of authentication coming
in current and future Keystone releases.  This supports all of the
authentication options specified at:
http://www.jamielennox.net/blog/2015/02/17/loading-authentication-plugins/

4) Cleans up domain support in admin.pp and uses the new helper method

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support

Change-Id: I3d420e08c74e8a43f2431be7fd46198281438f13
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/86/180586/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Copyright (C) 2015 Red Hat # # Author: Rich Megginson <rmeggins@redhat.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # == Definition: keystone::authconfig # # This resource configures Keystone authentication resources for an OpenStack # service. It will manage the [keystone_authtoken] section in the given # config resource. It supports all of the authentication parameters specified # at http://www.jamielennox.net/blog/2015/02/17/loading-authentication-plugins/ # with the addition of the default domain for user and project. # # == Parameters: # # [*name*] # The name of the resource corresponding to the config file. For example, # keystone::authconfig { 'glance_api_config': ... } # Where 'glance_api_config' is the name of the resource used to manage # the glance api configuration. # string; required # # [*user_name*] # The name of the service user; # string; required # # [*password*] # Password to create for the service user; # string; required # # [*auth_plugin*] # The plugin to use for authentication. # string; optional: default to 'password' # # [*auth_url*] # The URL to use for authentication. You are strongly encouraged to use # this. If not given, an URL will be constructed from the auth_host, # auth_port, auth_protocol, and auth_version_url parameters. # string; optional # # [*auth_host*] # (optional) DEPRECATED Host running auth service. # Defaults to '127.0.0.1'. Use auth_url instead. # # [*auth_port*] # (optional) DEPRECATED Port to use for auth service on auth_host. # Defaults to '35357'. Use auth_url instead. # # [*auth_protocol*] # (optional) DEPRECATED Protocol to use for auth. # Defaults to 'http'. Use auth_url instead. # # [*auth_version_url*] # (optional) DEPRECATED URL auth version suffix. Use this # if you want to force a particular auth suffix to be used. # If undef, the client will use most appropriate auth suffix # based on other parameters. # Defaults to undef. Use auth_url instead. # # [*user_id*] # The ID of the service user; # string; optional: default to undef # # [*user_domain_name*] # (Optional) Name of domain for $user_name # Defaults to undef # # [*user_domain_id*] # (Optional) ID of domain for $user_name # Defaults to undef # # [*project_name*] # Service project name; # string; optional: default to undef # # [*project_id*] # Service project ID; # string; optional: default to undef # # [*project_domain_name*] # (Optional) Name of domain for $project_name # Defaults to undef # # [*project_domain_id*] # (Optional) ID of domain for $project_name # Defaults to undef # # [*domain_name*] # (Optional) Use this for auth to obtain a domain-scoped token. # If using this option, do not specify $project_name or $project_id. # Defaults to undef # # [*domain_id*] # (Optional) Use this for auth to obtain a domain-scoped token. # If using this option, do not specify $project_name or $project_id. # Defaults to undef # # [*default_domain_name*] # (Optional) Name of domain for $user_name and $project_name # If user_domain_name is not specified, use $default_domain_name # If project_domain_name is not specified, use $default_domain_name # Defaults to undef # # [*default_domain_id*] # (Optional) ID of domain for $user_id and $project_id # If user_domain_id is not specified, use $default_domain_id # If project_domain_id is not specified, use $default_domain_id # Defaults to undef # # [*trust_id*] # (Optional) Trust ID # Defaults to undef # # [*cacert*] # (Optional) CA certificate file for TLS (https) # Defaults to undef # # [*cert*] # (Optional) Certificate file for TLS (https) # Defaults to undef # # [*key*] # (Optional) Key file for TLS (https) # Defaults to undef # # [*insecure*] # If true, explicitly allow TLS without checking server cert against any # certificate authorities. WARNING: not recommended. Use with caution. # boolean; Defaults to false (which means be secure) # define keystone::resource::authconfig( $username, $password, $auth_plugin = 'password', $auth_url = undef, $auth_host = '127.0.0.1', $auth_port = '35357', $auth_protocol = 'http', $auth_version_url = undef, $user_id = undef, $user_domain_name = undef, $user_domain_id = undef, $project_name = undef, $project_id = undef, $project_domain_name = undef, $project_domain_id = undef, $domain_name = undef, $domain_id = undef, $default_domain_name = undef, $default_domain_id = undef, $trust_id = undef, $cacert = undef, $cert = undef, $key = undef, $insecure = false, ) { # Must get either a project or a domain scoped token, so must either specify # a project or a domain if !$project_name and !$project_id and !$domain_name and !$domain_id { fail('Must specify either a project (project_name or project_id) or a domain (domain_name or domain_id)') } # Cannot specify both a project and a domain if ($project_name or $project_id) and ($domain_name or $domain_id) { fail('Cannot specify both a project (project_name or project_id) and a domain (domain_name or domain_id)') } if !$auth_url { if $auth_host { warning('The auth_host parameter is deprecated. Please use auth_url instead.') } if $auth_port { warning('The auth_port parameter is deprecated. Please use auth_url instead.') } if $auth_protocol { warning('The auth_protocol parameter is deprecated. Please use auth_url instead.') } if $auth_version_url { warning('The auth_version_url parameter is deprecated. Please use auth_url instead.') $real_auth_url = "${auth_protocol}://${auth_host}:${auth_port}/${auth_version_url}/" } else { # omit the version suffix in the url - the client will use most appropriate version $real_auth_url = "${auth_protocol}://${auth_host}:${auth_port}/" } } else { $real_auth_url = $auth_url } ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/auth_plugin', {'value' => $auth_plugin}) ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/auth_url', {'value' => $real_auth_url}) ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/username', {'value' => $username}) ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/password', {'value' => $password, 'secret' => true}) if $user_id { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/user_id', {'value' => $user_id}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/user_id', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $user_domain_name { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/user_domain_name', {'value' => $user_domain_name}) } elsif $default_domain_name { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/user_domain_name', {'value' => $default_domain_name}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/user_domain_name', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $user_domain_id { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/user_domain_id', {'value' => $user_domain_id}) } elsif $default_domain_id { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/user_domain_id', {'value' => $default_domain_id}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/user_domain_id', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $project_name { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_name', {'value' => $project_name}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_name', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $project_id { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_id', {'value' => $project_id}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_id', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $project_domain_name { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_domain_name', {'value' => $project_domain_name}) } elsif $default_domain_name { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_domain_name', {'value' => $default_domain_name}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_domain_name', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $project_domain_id { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_domain_id', {'value' => $project_domain_id}) } elsif $default_domain_id { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_domain_id', {'value' => $default_domain_id}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/project_domain_id', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $domain_name { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/domain_name', {'value' => $domain_name}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/domain_name', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $domain_id { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/domain_id', {'value' => $domain_id}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/domain_id', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $trust_id { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/trust_id', {'value' => $trust_id}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/trust_id', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $cacert { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/cacert', {'value' => $cacert}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/cacert', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $cert { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/cert', {'value' => $cert}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/cert', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } if $key { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/key', {'value' => $key}) } else { ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/key', {'ensure' => 'absent'}) } ensure_resource($name, 'keystone_authtoken/insecure', {'value' => $insecure}) }

subject: Remove from BridgeDevice homemade execute in namespace
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-08 23:02:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a8e0c3740914a12c0e292622d7c6de39c43f1463', 'message': 'Remove from BridgeDevice homemade execute in namespace

Currently BridgeDevice[1] defines homemade execute with namespace
support but could use IPDevice._as_root. This change replaces homemade
implementation with IPDevice._as_root use to respect DRY principle.

[1] neutron.agent.linux.bridge_lib

Change-Id: I12d4d40432e57ce8b6960276c41321c1efd98705
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-05-09 09:16:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0d1d9be53b4ed6ec2f01cf94886e79919de6e21c', 'message': 'Remove from BridgeDevice homemade execute in namespace

commit_message:
Remove from BridgeDevice homemade execute in namespace

Currently BridgeDevice[1] defines homemade execute with namespace
support but could use IPWrapper. This change replaces homemade
implementation with IPWrapper use to respect DRY principle.

[1] neutron.agent.linux.bridge_lib

Change-Id: I12d4d40432e57ce8b6960276c41321c1efd98705

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-17 08:30:39.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/common/ring/test_ring.py', 'swift/common/ring/ring.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/f2dfbc9d6209ddbd76f2a8165fb74e043b77cd73', 'message': "Use just IP on get_more_nodes, too

commit_message:
Use just IP on get_more_nodes, too

According to Sam's change[1], for now, we should change
get_more_nodes's 3rd tier to use just ip instead of ip_ports
to make cluster's failure domain to be mapped to actual hardware.
See [1] in detail.

Tiers definition here is as:
1st: Region, 2nd: Zone, 3rd: Ip (previously Ip_ports), 4th: Device

In addition, if we keep current behavior and assign different
ports to each disk in the node, get_more_nodes would do device
level search twice w/o ip level search. (at 3rd and 4th tier)
That's unfortunately wasted and not to ensure ip-level failure domain.

To fix such a situation, this patch changes get_more_nodes to use
just IP at the 3rd tier.

1: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/191970

Change-Id: I65d1b0ac904a074b235ed619d73cd0e33183b2c0

commit_message:
API Extensions: inherit from the ExtensionDescriptor

For consistency in the codebase, API extensions should inherit from the
abstract base class ExtensionDescriptor.

Change-Id: Id4829c265866e80c042c433bebcc01383e1e7417

commit_message:
Send mtu and vlan_transparent for network operations

We were previously removing these. But in the spirit of transparently
passing through all attributes and API calls from Neutron to ODL,
stop pruning these.

Change-Id: I741b7a4f53f6857499463a23b148dade14e41da2
Signed-off-by: Kyle Mestery <mestery@mestery.com>

sshd_config by adding Match blocks to securely allow root SSH[2]. When
beaker tries to append the PermitUserEnvironment line after the Match

commit_message:
Unpin beaker-rspec

The latest version of beaker tries to manage sshd_config[1] in order to
pass through environment variables. JJB also tries to manage
sshd_config by adding Match blocks to securely allow root SSH[2]. When
beaker tries to append the PermitUserEnvironment line after the Match
blocks, SSH fails to open port 22 and beaker can't SSH in to the
node[3]. This patch unpins beaker-rspec and adds set_env: false to the
nodepool nodesets so that the set_env method is never called and does
not try to mess with the sshd_config.

[1] https://github.com/puppetlabs/beaker/blob/master/lib/beaker/host_prebuilt_steps.rb#L528
[2] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/project-config/tree/jenkins/jobs/puppet-module-jobs.yaml#n42
[3] http://logs.openstack.org/61/185161/1/check/gate-puppet-nova-puppet-beaker-rspec-dsvm-centos7/cd81608/console.html.gz#_2015-05-22_22_05_46_933
[4] https://github.com/puppetlabs/beaker/blob/master/lib/beaker/host_prebuilt_steps.rb#L502

Change-Id: I9752fd76266fcaf7ad27703799967d5468317781
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-glance refs/changes/36/189436/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Added documentation to Vagrantfile

A couple of comments during my latest CORS review indicated that
there is a misunderstanding on why the Vagrantfile in ironic exists.
In those comments, the assumption appeared to be that vagrant is used
to provision ironic, not just the development resources necessary to
work on ironic. This patch adds documentation to clarify that.

Change-Id: I7d71adaba402a62343d1e0399ee53410b76c973f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/12/191912/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # WARNING: This vagrantfile is for development purposes only. It is intended to # bootstrap required services - such as mysql and rabbit - into a reliably # accessible VM, rather than forcing the engineer to install and manage these # services manually. This Vagrantfile is not intended to assist in provisioning # Ironic. For that, please use the bifrost project.

commit_message:
nova_powervm.virt.powervm.mgmt.rescan_scsi_bus

Add utility to rescan the SCSI bus, optionally with the 'remove' flag.

This is to be used when mapping instance disks to the management
partition, e.g. for the snapshot function.

Change-Id: Iea29cd2916607e1420ebb9654de3608c6534e6a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/08/186908/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mock @mock.patch('nova.utils.execute') def test_rescan_scsi_bus(self, mock_exec): mgmt.rescan_scsi_bus() mock_exec.assert_called_with( '/usr/bin/rescan-scsi-bus.sh', run_as_root=True) mock_exec.reset_mock() mgmt.rescan_scsi_bus(remove=False) mock_exec.assert_called_with( '/usr/bin/rescan-scsi-bus.sh', run_as_root=True) mock_exec.reset_mock() mgmt.rescan_scsi_bus(remove=True) mock_exec.assert_called_with( '/usr/bin/rescan-scsi-bus.sh', '-r', run_as_root=True)

commit_message:
Fix TypeError exception during cancel stack update

TypeError: call() takes exactly 3 arguments(5 given) is raised
during cancel stack update, this patch will fix the problem.

Change-Id: If85389150a15575d9e01466d950f8c07b8fa2717
Closes-Bug: #1448384
(cherry picked from commit 72403962033d15bfe910eae14f01a4461d1789e9)

commit_message:
Update version for Liberty

Update the version for Liberty, switching from date-based versioning
to pre-versioning using SemVer. See
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/065211.html
and
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/067082.html
for details.

Change-Id: I6a35fa0dda798fad93b804d00a46af80f08d475c

commit_message:
Update devstack to handle Trove/Neutron setups

Default Trove configuration (for task manager and service) don't
reflect the settings required for Neutron. Trove requires a
configuration that can only be done after neutron is up. This
introduces a new function called just before starting trove services.

Change-Id: I197ec2d3975f7b551590cf1f6c7d2cb42d479e25
Closes-Bug: #1435612
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/94/189394/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # finalize_trove_network() - do the last thing(s) before starting Trove function finalize_trove_network { management_network_id=$(neutron --os-tenant-name admin --os-username admin --os-password $ADMIN_PASSWORD net-list | grep $PRIVATE_NETWORK_NAME | awk '{print $2}') echo "finalize_trove_network: found network id $management_network_id" iniset $TROVE_CONF DEFAULT network_label_regex .* iniset $TROVE_CONF DEFAULT ip_regex .* iniset $TROVE_CONF DEFAULT blacklist_regex ^10.0.1.* iniset $TROVE_CONF DEFAULT default_neutron_networks $management_network_id iniset $TROVE_CONF DEFAULT network_driver trove.network.neutron.NeutronDriver iniset $TROVE_TASKMANAGER_CONF DEFAULT network_driver trove.network.neutron.NeutronDriver iniset $TROVE_TASKMANAGER_CONF mysql tcp_ports 22,3306 } # finish the last step in trove network configuration echo_summary "Finalizing Trove Network Configuration" if is_service_enabled neutron; then echo "finalize_trove_network: Neutron is enabled." finalize_trove_network else echo "finalize_trove_network: Neutron is not enabled. Nothing to do." fi

commit_message:
Remove cloud-init details

If we have booted with cloud-init, then this status directory is
populated.  Remove it so when we boot snapshot images, they behave as
if on a fresh system.

Change-Id: Idc9ce01290b659e3239d30be847221447a8e5e84

added_lines: # reset cloud-init sudo rm -rf /var/lib/cloud/instances

subject: Remove mount of ephemeral disk
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-18 04:06:27.000000000', 'files': ['nodepool/scripts/prepare_node.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/a9444cdad8b0bb44ac79fd5f5576bf97449a968e', 'message': "Remove mount of ephemeral disk

hpcloud has started sending metadata to cloud-init to mount ephemeral
disks.  This ends up writing a fstab entry for /dev/vdb.

---
$ curl http://169.254.169.254/2009-04-04/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ephemeral0
/dev/vdb
---

It's unclear why this just started happening, but it did.

devstack-gate later attempts to repartition this into swap & disk
space and mount it elsewhere.  So remove this mount from fstab -- it
shouldn't come back because the next thing we do here is tell
cloud-init to not use the metadata source.

Change-Id: I3787d0f7e5139e891686ffbb2970e65d09f112b1
"}]
commit_message:
Remove mount of ephemeral disk

hpcloud has started sending metadata to cloud-init to mount ephemeral
disks.  This ends up writing a fstab entry for /dev/vdb.

---
$ curl http://169.254.169.254/2009-04-04/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ephemeral0
/dev/vdb
---

It's unclear why this just started happening, but it did.

devstack-gate later attempts to repartition this into swap & disk
space and mount it elsewhere.  So remove this mount from fstab -- it
shouldn't come back because the next thing we do here is tell
cloud-init to not use the metadata source.

Change-Id: I3787d0f7e5139e891686ffbb2970e65d09f112b1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/63/192963/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # hpcloud has started mounting ephemeral /dev/vdb at /mnt. # devstack-gate wants to partition the ephemeral disk, add some swap # and mount it at /opt. get rid of the mount. # # note this comes down from the cloud-init metadata; which we setup to # ignore below. sudo sed -i '/^\/dev\/vdb/d' /etc/fstab

commit_message:
Set some more defaults for Linux Bridge

Set Linux Bridge to use VLANs for tenant networks, and designate eth0 as
the physical interface.

Co-Authored-By: Jens Rosenboom <j.rosenboom@x-ion.de>
Change-Id: I7a6e391d6da558f5096bec7e71590c29f8a8806b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/07/192907/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG="Q_AGENT=linuxbridge"$'
'"ENABLE_TENANT_VLANS=True"$'
'" PHYSICAL_NETWORK=default"$'
'"TENANT_VLAN_RANGE=100:200"$'
'"LB_PHYSICAL_INTERFACE=eth0"

commit_message:
Switch from MySQL-python to PyMySQL

As discussed in the Liberty Design Summit "Moving apps to Python 3"
cross-project workshop, the way forward in the near future is to
switch to the pure-python PyMySQL library as a default.

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-cross-project-python3

Change-Id: If94671d03e36e737ed3557c1fc630540a506657e

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/065211.html
and

for details.

commit_message:
Add a mapped device to the management partition

New method nova_powervm.virt.powervm.mgmt.discover_vscsi_disk.

Based on a VSCSIMapping, scan the appropriate virtual SCSI host bus and
find the correct path of the newly-created device based on its UDID.

Change-Id: Id79b62fdd4f16f993b3563f20bc23d2d910f45a6

commit_message:
go: document replication

A little writeup on how the hummingbird replicator differs from python-swift.

Change-Id: I26c5c680bf866590f1ee7cbb4f1cd414af1aa5ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/44/193244/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Hummingbird Replication The hummingbird object server is backwards-compatible with the python-swift replicator, but the hummingbird replicator has a few improvements that only allow it to work with the hummingbird object server. A replication ID is sent with all requests to associate the calls for a single partition replication operation. This helps eliminate a common problem where we serve an expensive REPLICATE call, only to reject the subsequent rsync due to concurrency limits. The server can inexpensively reject the initial REPLICATE call if it's already at the incoming replication concurrency limit. The SYNC method replaces rsync for transmitting data. It functions like a simple PUT operation to the real destination file path relative to the root, and can accept .data, .meta, or .ts files. It looks something like: SYNC /sda/objects/123/fff/ffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff/12345.6789.data HTTP/1.1 X-Attrs: [hex-encoded xattr data] X-Replication-Id: [unique ID per partition replication] Content-Length: [size] Expect: 100-Continue SYNC request responses: 201: file was successfully uploaded 400: there was a problem with the request 409: this file or a newer one already exists 500: mostly caused by filesystem errors 507: disk unmounted or full The X-Attrs header contains the hex-encoded raw pickled metadata from the file's xattrs. If the replicator receives a 409 response with the "Newer-File-Exists: true" header, the file is stale and can be removed. It's hoped that this will reduce the incidence of orphaned object data that can occur with long-lived handoffs. Since the SYNC method invalidates hashes, the followup REPLICATE call to force the server to recalculate suffixes is no longer required. However, an "end" request is sent to inform the server that the replication pass has finished, and it can remove that replication ID from its concurrency accounting.

commit_message:
Remove duplicated debug logging around locking

Currently, iptables_manager.py does extra unnecessary logging about lock
acquisition and release. It uses lockutils.lock() which passes
do_log=True by default, which causes lockutils.lock() to do debug
logging about lock acquisition/release. IptablesManager itself also writes
debug log info about lock acquisition and release.

This change will eliminate unnecessary duplicate logging in order to
reduce log noise about locking. This change is also related to
https://github.com/harlowja/fasteners/commit/f88f2fea7fe250b7d26cdcbc84633ccbbc68eeee
which reduces the logging level in the underlying lock implementation
used by oslo.concurrency. That change along with this one will remove
the duplicate debug logging about locking in iptables_manager.py and also in
ipset_manager.py.

Change-Id: If6f4a7101f3783ad83645e28bbb5c577dd403d3b
Closes-Bug: 1464727

So we can determine # if a normal restore is enough for initial creation. # That should speed up agent boot up time. else: add_ips = self._get_new_set_ips(set_name, member_ips) del_ips = self._get_deleted_set_ips(set_name, member_ips) if (len(add_ips) + len(del_ips) < IPSET_ADD_BULK_THRESHOLD): self._add_members_to_set(set_name, add_ips) self._del_members_from_set(set_name, del_ips) else: self._refresh_set(set_name, member_ips, ethertype) def destroy(self, id, ethertype, forced=False): with utils.lockutils.lock('ipset', utils.SYNCHRONIZED_PREFIX, True, do_log=False): set_name = self.get_name(id, ethertype) self._destroy(set_name, forced)

commit_message:
Enable loadbalancing of the Redis VIP, defaults to False

We have to set it to true as the default is false which means the
redis vip can't be reached. This was manifested as a problem with
ceilometer agent reaching the coordination url like [1].

Co-Authored-By: Giulio Fidente <gfidente@redhat.com>

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/attachment.cgi?id=1040023
Closes-Bug: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1232797
Change-Id: I1cd63308d0ac1d17542e1a2a909ee1a9680ed4b3

commit_message:
Fix MD5 headers regression

This regression was introduced when we switched to
swiftclient.service.SwiftService for uploading because of a
documentation bug. The option was listed as 'headers' but it should be
'header'.

Change-Id: Id590f624aa084af0747b93ae70b214600147ebb2

update_acl( self.app, 'containers', container_id, uuid.uuid4().hex, read_creator_only=False, expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 404) def test_update_container_acl_when_no_acls_defined_should_fail(self): """Update should fail when no container acls are defined.""" container_id, _ = create_container(self.app) resp = update_acl( self.app, 'containers', container_id, uuid.uuid4().hex, read_creator_only=False, expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 404) def test_delete_secret_acl_with_valid_acl_id(self): """Delete existing 200) acl_map = _get_acl_map(container_id, is_secret=False) self.assertIsNone(acl_map.get('list')) # list acl should be deleted def test_delete_secret_acls_invalid_secret_should_fail(self): """Delete list_creator_only=list_creator_only, is_update=False, write_user_ids=None, list_user_ids=None, read_creator_only=None, write_creator_only=None, list_creator_only=None, list_creator_only=None, is_update=False, expect_errors=False): if is_update: '/{0}/{1}/acls'.format(entity_type, entity_id), else: resp = app.post_json( '/{0}/{1}/acls'.format(entity_type, entity_id), acl_ids = None if resp.status_int in (201, 200): acl_ids = [] for acl in resp.json: acl_ids.append(_get_entity_id(acl)) return (resp, acl_ids) def update_acl(app, entity_type, entity_id, acl_id, read_user_ids=None, write_user_ids=None, list_user_ids=None, read_creator_only=None, write_creator_only=None, list_creator_only=None, expect_errors=False): request = {} _append_acl_to_request(request, 'read', read_user_ids, read_creator_only) _append_acl_to_request(request, 'write', write_user_ids, write_creator_only) _append_acl_to_request(request, 'list', list_user_ids, list_creator_only) cleaned_request = {key: val for key, val in request.items() if val is not None} resp = app.patch_json( '/{0}/{1}/acls/{2}'.format(entity_type, entity_id, acl_id), cleaned_request, expect_errors=expect_errors) def _get_entity_id(acl): return os.path.split(acl.get('acl_ref', ''))[-1]

commit_message:
Remove Future Parameters (write, list, delete) from ACL Validation Schema

Updated the validation schema for ACLs.
  - Removed write, list, and delete operations since they are not yet supported.
  - Added line for no additional properties other than "users" and "creator_only"
  - Added unit tests covering all of these and other conditions.
  - Updated unit tests to limit to "read" ACLs
  - Removed unit tests covering cases with more than one operation

Change-Id: Ie8a3abd22d02bb4a7bbedad373efa7435f3bdb3b
Closes-Bug: #1447872
(cherry picked from commit 1fa86f707e0b4b5923268fb34c87026d390e0eef)

read operation value is changed self.assertEqual('read', acl['operation']) self.assertEqual(set(['u1', 'u2', 'u5']), set(acl['users'])) acl_map = _get_acl_map(container_id, is_secret=False) # list, write operation should not be changed self.assertIsNone(acl_map.get('write')) self.assertFalse(acl_map['list']['creator_only']) list_users = acl_map['list'].to_dict_fields()['users'] self.assertEqual(set(['u1', 'u3', 'u4']), set(list_users)) def test_update_container_acl_modify_different_operation_should_fail(self): """Should fail as modifying existing acl's operation is not allowed.""" container_id, _ = create_container(self.app) _, _ = create_acls( self.app, 'containers', container_id, read_user_ids=['u1', 'u2'], list_user_ids=['u1', 'u3', 'u4']) acl_map = _get_acl_map(container_id, is_secret=False) acl_id = acl_map['read']['id'] # updating with list ACL should fail as originally read operation # ACL is associated with acl_id and cannot be modified. resp = update_acl( self.app, 'containers', container_id, acl_id, list_user_ids=['u1', 'u3'], list_creator_only=True, expect_errors=True) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 400) read_creator_only=True, list_user_ids=['u1', 'u3', 'u4']) read_creator_only=True, list_user_ids=['u1', 'u3', 'u4']) read_creator_only=False, list_user_ids=['u1', 'u3', 'u4'], list_creator_only=None, write_creator_only=True) read_creator_only=False, list_user_ids=['u1', 'u3', 'u4'], list_creator_only=None, write_creator_only=True) list_acl_id = acl_map['list'].id '/containers/{0}/acls/{1}'.format(container_id, list_acl_id), self.assertIsNone(acl_map.get('list')) # list acl should be deleted read_creator_only=False, list_user_ids=['u1', 'u3', 'u4'], list_creator_only=None, write_creator_only=True) write_user_ids=None, list_user_ids=None, read_creator_only=None, write_creator_only=None, list_creator_only=None, write_user_ids=write_user_ids, list_user_ids=list_user_ids, write_creator_only=write_creator_only, list_creator_only=list_creator_only, is_update=False, write_user_ids=None, list_user_ids=None, read_creator_only=None, write_creator_only=None, list_creator_only=None, write_user_ids=write_user_ids, list_user_ids=list_user_ids, write_creator_only=write_creator_only, list_creator_only=list_creator_only, is_update=True, write_user_ids=None, list_user_ids=None, read_creator_only=None, write_creator_only=None, list_creator_only=None, is_update=False, _append_acl_to_request(request, 'write', write_user_ids, write_creator_only) _append_acl_to_request(request, 'list', list_user_ids, list_creator_only) write_user_ids=None, list_user_ids=None, read_creator_only=None, write_creator_only=None, list_creator_only=None, expect_errors=False): _append_acl_to_request(request, 'write', write_user_ids, write_creator_only) _append_acl_to_request(request, 'list', list_user_ids, list_creator_only)

commit_message:
HMAC signature based token

Change-Id: I12e6a9f312ea49691d40db546a712e9a6838de82
Implements: bp hmac-signature-based-token
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/03/153803/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================== HMAC Signature Based Token ========================== `bp hmac-signature-based-token <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/hmac-signature-based-token>`_ Hash-based message authentication code is prevalent in Cryptography to simultaneously verify both the data integrity and the authentication of a message. See `Hash-based message authentication code <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash-based_message_authentication_code>`_ This specification proposes use of HMAC signature technique for generation and validation of user authentication token. Verification of data integrity and authentication of a message will validate the user authentication and claims. This technique is already used in OpenStack Object Storage to generate and validate temporary access URL for objects. See `Temporary URL <http://docs.openstack.org/juno/config-reference/content/ object-storage-tempurl.html>`_ for more information on Temporary URL. Problem Description =================== There are following two types of tokens are supported by Keystone currently. ``UUID Tokens``: These tokens are clear text JSON documents provided to users after successful authentication. Token contains service endpoints and roles to operate on the service. User access resources by presenting the `tokens_id` to service. Users claims their authenticity and rights to access the resources owned by their project. Service (middle-ware) validates the claim by validating the token from Keystone. ``PKI Tokens``: These are PKI encrypted form of the UUID tokens provided to the users after successful authentication. Users have to presents the entire cypher text to the service to access the resources. Claim validation will be done by decrypting the cypher text and validating the signature. In a cloud deployment, all services (Keystone, Compute, Cinder) share the same PKI keys to make the validation successes. Below are the problems with the above two token style: * Token documents are relatively big data stored in database, which imposes maintainability overhead to the cloud operations. * In large-scale cloud deployments token document size may grow significantly big, which can lead to database grow out of hand. * As part of `UUID` token validation process, Keystone has to provide entire token data to the service over the network. This causes extra network overhead; in large-scale high traffic cloud deployments this can not be scalable approach. * PKI tokens are large encrypted data, which users are supposed to send to service over request header. Growing number of regions and availability zones in a cloud setup can easily increase the size of token data to allowed limit. * Services have to share same PKI artifacts (private key) that can cause as big security gap. Proposed Change =============== There is a need of an intermediate solution which reduces the persistence aspect and also reduce transmitting large data over network. A new token provider will be added to the Keystone service, which will responsible for generation of HMAC based tokens. The new token provider will be preserving the current token structure with added HMAC signature constructs in the service catalog section, per endpoint. New cryptographic key (a.k.a. HMAC-Key) will be generated for each token request; this key will be used to generate the HMAC signature in the token for each endpoints. Message to generate the signature will be constructed using service_id, region_id, endpoint URL, project_id, user roles on project and token expiration time. This way HMAC signature will be bind to an expiration time. User will be required to provide the HMAC signature and expiration time on query parameter (or in separate header) along with the `token_id` in `X-Auth-Header`. They are also required to provide necessary information (e.g. service_id, region_id, endpoint URL, project_id, user roles on project) so that the middleware can rebuild the message to generate the signature. Middleware will query Keystone to collect the `HMAC-Key` associated with the token_id. In response Keystone will provide the `HMAC-Key` along with expiration time as long as the key is not expired. Middleware will generate the message using the information provided by user, it will also include the expiration time provided by user from query string. Message digest will generated for the message, using HMAC-Key and same hash algorithm (e.g. Sha-256, Sha-512) which was used by Keystone to generate the signature. Validation will be done by matching the message digest with the signature provided by user. Signature validation will fail if user is trying to fool the system by any means. Following are some approaches to manage and maintenance of these keys: 1. Generate HMAC-Keys per token request and store in database. We will not be storing entire token data only `token_id`, `hmac_key` and `expiration_time` will be stored. While validation signature Keystone will handover `hmac_key` and `expiration_time` to the middleware, which will cache this data till its expiration for future use. ``Pros``: Less maintenance, less network footprint. ``Cons``: Caching infrastructure for middleware, token revocation will be trouble. Use notification framework (revocation event) to revoke tokens. 2. Generate HMAC-Keys per token per endpoint and store in database. In this case we will be storing `token_id`, `endpoint_id`, `hmac_key` and `expiration_time`. While validation signature Keystone will handover `hmac_key` and `expiration_time` to the middleware based on endpoint_id. In this model Keystone can delete the key after giving it to the middleware. ``Pros``: True Ephemeral for Keystone, Less maintenance, less network footprint. ``Cons``: Caching infrastructure for middleware, token revocation will be trouble as there is no handle left with Keystone to track the key. 3. Generate HMAC-Keys per token request and store in database (as per option #1). Maintain an in-memory small cache of Keys in Keystone to avoid database lookup per request. Provide the HMAC-key to middleware for each validation request for the same token. Alternatively, middleware can pass the message and signature, Keystone will validate signature and respond with Yes/On like result. In this model HMAC-key will not leave Keystone. ``Pros``: More secure and token revocation is on control. * Reduces the persistence aspect to minimal. Entire token document vs just `token_id`,`hmac_key` and `expiration_time`. * Very small data set to manage, operation will be easy. * Least change in the token format. * Very light weight as compared to PKI. * No need to share PKI keys. * Reduces over the network data exchanges for validation response. ``Cons``: Keystone has to maintain the keys per token in DB. Note: We need to consider storing `user_id` and `project_id` to support different token revocation use cases. Alternatives ------------ There was a proposal for AE tokens, which is encrypted token. Relatively bigger than the HMAC token. At the same time validation process is also transmitting bigger data between Keystone and service. Data Model Impact ----------------- We have to store token_id, hmac-key and expiration; for that we can use the current data model or we can have totally separate model for this token provider. REST API Impact --------------- Token response will have added fields for HMAC signature and expiration. Note: We can use the expiration field from token for signature expiration and get rid of one extra filed. Following is an example of token response with HMAC signature. .. code-block:: javascript Headers: X-Subject-Token X-Subject-Token: e80b74 { "token": { "methods": [ "password" ], "roles": [ { "id": "f8c883654d744166b9d23e937837b146", "name": "admin" } ], "expires_at": "2015-01-29T01:59:31.576241Z", "project": { "domain": { "id": "4543da6f81e44fc8b013a740ef71f9e8", "name": "test-domain" }, "id": "86741b3f86ce4784bd77045a735db5d1", "name": "test-project" }, "catalog": [ { "endpoints": [ { "region_id": "us-east", "url": "http://mycloud.com:39390/compute", "region": "us-east", "interface": "public", "id": "d2275aeb928445bd8792cd67ee9c5f8d", "sig": "3d1b53987a4ece5b496abd2245522daee79 a1d0f73e4579e6a0495b22e4338ca", "expires_at": "1422646386" } ], "type": "compute", "id": "cf64bbc58c0446d786da4145a517866b", "name": "Nova" } ], "extras": {}, "user": { "domain": { "id": "4543da6f81e44fc8b013a740ef71f9e8", "name": "test-domain" }, "id": "3c9891dd12644437bf935b46d2dbd379", "name": "Arvind Tiwari" }, "audit_ids": [ "mztfYOmpTGy6O8oVsKlj1w" ], "issued_at": "2015-01-29T00:59:31.576283Z" } } Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployer have to configure new token provider. Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Arvind Tiwari (atiwari) Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- 1. Implement the new token provider. 2. Keystone python client changes. 3. Middleware changes need to support HMAC signature validation. 4. Keystone token validation flow will be modified. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= There will be unit tests. For integration tests, we need spin up a Keystone instance with HMAC token provider. Documentation Impact ==================== 1. Update Keystone configuration doc on how to use the HMAC token provider. 2. Update Keystone middleware configuration doc on how to use HMAC token. References ========== * `Temporary URL <http://docs.openstack.org/juno/config-reference/content/object-storage-tempurl.html>`_ * `Hash-based message authentication code <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash-based_message_authentication_code>`_

commit_message:
Revert "Switch defaults to stable/6.1"

Due to bug[1] in Gerrit, 6,1-only patchset has been applied  to master. We
obviously want to track master in master branch

This reverts commit 218e92475d249ae3290f8d8343b14105b10412cd.

[1] https://code.google.com/p/gerrit/issues/detail?id=1107

Change-Id: Ic7ce1eea2baa279b7fee5f837922451dedfef7cc
Closes-Bug: 1466640
